DOC.HEAD: New Charity Named After Lockerbie Victim
With AM-Flight 103, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A new charity to aid Third World countries was launched Thursday in memory of the United Nations Commissioner for Namibia who was killed in the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing. The Bernt Carlsson Trust, named after the commissioner, was launched on the first anniversary of the bombing. Carlsson, a Swede, had been on his way to New York to sign a Namibian peace settlement and was one of the 270 victims. Glenys Kinnock, wife of opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock, said the charity would funds for Namibia, formerly South African-controlled South-West Africa. ``Our aims are to have some memorial to Bernt Carlsson who spent his life, dedicating his life to relieving poverty in the developing world,'' said Mrs. Kinnock, who is heading the trust. Carlsson's brother, Tore, attended the launch of the charity. The trustees include rock star Peter Townsend of The Who.
